<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_irq_shutdown:
```c
void metal_linux_irq_shutdown(void)
{
	int ret;

	metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "%s\n", __func__);
	irq_handling_stop = true;
	metal_linux_irq_notify();
	ret = pthread_join(irq_pthread, NULL);
	if (ret) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "Failed to join IRQ thread: %d.\n",
			  ret);
	}
	close(irq_notify_fd);
	metal_mutex_deinit(&irq_lock);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Fragments not listed do not present pointer targets that could be const-qualified and therefore do not need investigation for Rule 8.13: - The assignment irq_handling_stop = true; involves a scalar boolean control variable, not a pointer. - metal_linux_irq_notify(); is a call with no arguments and thus no pointer parameters to check. - The if (ret) { ... } block and the metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, ...) call only use integer values (ret) and format strings, not pointer targets requiring const qualification. - close(irq_notify_fd); operates on an integer file descriptor, not a pointer. Other pointer uses in the listed suspicious fragments should be investigated to determine whether the pointed-to types could/should be const-qualified.
